articles.title: About This Workshop
articles.contents:
The purpose of this workshop is to elicit expert knowledge on the current geographic range of established invasive species that will be used to project future range shifts or expansions over time.
Breakfast and lunch will be provided.
For any further information regarding this workshop and how these results will be used, please contact xxxx at zzzz.
Prior to attendance
Participants are asked to complete a trial of the Shiny app to familiarize themselves with the process before attending the workshop (for 3 spp.)
What to bring
Laptop or tablet
Your thoughtful contributions

articles.title: SECASC Invasive Species Expert Elicitation Workshop
articles.description:
April 27-28, 2022
Austin Cary Forest Campus
University of Florida, Gainesville, FL
articles.contents:
This expert elicitation workshop aims to use expert elicitation to assess invasive species risk throughout the southeastern US. We have developed a purpose built web application that will be used to collate expert knowledge to produce models of current species distributions and future distributions under climate change. The workshop would focus on approximately 10-15 invasive species that are currently, or have the potential to be, highly detrimental to ecosystems of the SE US. These species come from our initial meeting over Zoom in Autumn 2021 where we ranked species. Thus, this first workshop is quite focused on taxonomic expertise in distribution and ecological/trait data. We will then have a second workshop where we explore management options in light of outputs from workshop 1.
This workshop is supported by ABC funding sources and is hosted by XYZ people and organizations.
Invited participants will provide their insight on invasive species habitat suitability and occupancy through an interactive web application created with R Shiny. This web app can be accessed from the ‘App’ tab at the top of the page or through the link to shinyapps.io.

articles.title: Workshop Itinerary
articles.contents:
April 27, 2022
8:00 am      - Shuttle pickup at hotel 9:00 am - 10:00 am      - Meet and greet - opening presentation by Brett Scheffers with overview of project      - Introductions 10:30 am - 11:00 am      - Coffee/tea break 11:00 am - 12:30 pm      - Introduction to virtual maps (Josh Cullen)      - Completion of virtual maps by all participants      - Group discussion about data availability of species-specific habitat, climate, traits,        life history information 12:30 pm - 1:30 pm      - Lunch 1:30 pm - 3:00 pm      - Breakout groups to discuss, review, and populate checklists of life-history and        physiology traits needed for connectivity modelling (e.g., thermal tolerances,        reproductive output, etc) 3:00 pm - 3:30 pm      - Coffee/tea break 3:30 pm - 5:00 pm      - TBD - e.g., whole group discussion of data compilation (e.g., existing occurrence        data, suitability models, etc) 5:00 pm - 8:00 pm      - Shuttle back to hotel      - Optional happy hour in town - TBD      - Optional Dinner - TBD 

April 28, 2022
8:30 am      - Shuttle pickup at hotel. For those flying out today, please bring luggage to        workshop for afternoon departure. 9:00 am - 10:30 am      - Review and discuss processed expert elicited maps; maps will be generated        overnight from data collected on Day 1 and participants will rate each map from 0-1. 10:30 am - 11:00 am      - Coffee/tea break 11:00 am - 12:30 pm      - Review and discuss processed expert elicited maps; maps will be generated        overnight from data collected on Day 1 and participants will rate each map from 0-1. 12:30 pm - 1:30 pm      - Lunch 1:30 pm - 3:00 pm      - Discussion of modelling approaches for checklist species      - Compile and provide list of management options 3:00 pm - 3:30 pm      - Coffee/tea break 3:30 pm - 5:00 pm      - Next steps and action items 5:30 pm      - Shuttle back to hotel 7:00 pm      - Dinner location TBA (attendance optional)
